columns.text: In this problem, we have to calculate the operating cash flow of a new project by using four different methods or approaches and then verify that all approaches give the same answer,

**Operating cash flow** is the cash generated by the business during the normal course of its operation. 

While calculating operating cash flow, all the non-cash expenses such as depreciation are added back to the **Earnings Before Interest and Taxes (EBIT).**

EBIT as the name suggests is the revenue of the organization before the interest and the taxes are taken into account. Generally, if the company is profitable, it will have a high EBIT.

The four approaches to calculating the operating cash flow  $(\text{OCF})$ are as follows:

The first is the **Basic approach**. Here, the $\text{OCF}$ is calculated in the following manner:

$$\text{OCF}=\text{EBIT+Depreciation-Taxes}$$

The second is the **Bottom-Up approach**. Here, the $\text{OCF}$ is calculated in the following manner:

$$\text{OCF}=\text{Net Income+Depreciation}$$ 

It must be noted that net income is the difference between the EBIT and the taxes.

The third is the **Top-Down approach**. Here, the $\text{OCF}$ is calculated in the following manner:

$$\text{OCF}=\text{Sales - Costs - Taxes}$$

The fourth is the **Tax Shield approach**. Here, the $\text{OCF}$ in the following manner:

$$\text{OCF}=\text{[(Sales - Costs)$\cdot$(1-Tax Rate)]+(Depreciation$\cdot$Tax Rate)}$$

The following information about the new project is available:


|**Particulars** | **Amount**| 
|--|--| 
|Sales |$175,000 | 
|Costs |$93,000 | 
|Depreciation | $24,800| 

The tax rate is $23\%$
.

## 1. Basic Approach

Using the first approach mentioned in the third step to calculate the Operating Cash Flow, we will first find the value of EBIT.

We know,

$$\text{EBIT= Sales - Cost -Depreciation}$$
Accordingly, we have 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\$175,000-\$93,000-\$24,800\\
&=\$57,200
\end{aligned}$$

Thus we have the Earnings before interest and taxes as $\$57,200$

We need the tax amount as well. The tax will be calculated on the EBIT. Accordingly,
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax}&=\$57,200 \cdot 23\%\\
&=\$57,200 \cdot \frac{23}{100}\\[15pt]
&=\$13,156
\end{aligned}$$

Thus we have the tax amount as $\$13,156$

Now we will find the $\text{OCF}$


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=\$57,200+\$24,800-\$13,156\\
&=\$68,844
\end{aligned}$$ 

Therefore, **using the basic approach the operating cash flow comes out to be $\$68,844$**

## 2. Bottom-Up Approach

Using the second approach mentioned in the fourth step to calculate the Operating Cash flow.

We know, $\text{EBIT}=\$57,200$ and $\text{Tax}=\$13,156$ . Also,

$$\text{Net Income=EBIT-Taxes}$$
Accordingly, 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net Income}&=\$57,200 -\$13,156\\
&=\$44,044
\end{aligned}$$

Thus we have $\$44,044$ as the net income.

Now we will find the $\text{OCF}$


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=\$44,044+\$24,800\\
&=\$68,844
\end{aligned}$$ 

Therefore, **using the bottom-up approach the operating cash flow comes out to be $\$68,844$.**

## 3. Top-Down Approach

Using the third approach mentioned in the fifth step to calculate the Operating Cash flow.


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=\$175,000-\$93,000-\$13,156\\
&=\$68,844
\end{aligned}$$ 

Therefore, **using the top-down approach the operating cash flow comes out to be $\$68,844$.**

## 4. Tax Shield Approach
Using the fourth approach mentioned in the sixth step to calculate the Operating Cash flow.


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\$175,000-\$93,000)\cdot(1-0.23)]+(\$24,800\cdot0.23)\\
&=(\$82,000\cdot0.67)+\$5,704\\
&=\$63,140+\$5,704\\
&=\$68,844
\end{aligned}$$ 

Therefore, **using the tax shield approach the operating cash flow comes out to be $\$68,844$.**

Thus, it can be observed that the operating cash flow, using any of the above-mentioned approaches comes out to be $\$68,844$. Therefore, it can be concluded that the verification is successful that any of **the four approaches to calculating OCF gives the same answer.**
